section.title: Introduction
section.para: A MacPorts port has ten distinct phases. The MacPorts base is set to perform default steps for applications that use the standard configure, make, and make install steps, but for applications that do not conform to this behavior, installation phases may be declared in a Portfile to augment or override the default behavior as described in the Portfile Development chapter.

section.title: Fetch
section.para: Overview: Fetch the ${distfiles} from ${master_sites} and place it in ${prefix}/var/macports/distfiles.

section.title: Checksum
section.para: Overview: Compare ${checksums} specified in a Portfile to the checksums of the fetched ${distfiles}.

section.title: Extract
section.para: Overview: Unzip and untar the ${distfiles} into the path ${prefix}/var/macports/build/..../work

section.title: Patch
section.para: Overview: Apply optional patch files specified in ${patchfiles} to modify a port's source code file(s).
Details: Patch files are made using the diff command, and MacPorts patches should be created as unified diffs.

section.title: Configure
section.para: Overview: Execute the command "configure" in ${workpath}.

section.title: Build
section.para: Overview: Execute the command "make" in ${workpath}.

section.title: Destroot
section.para: Overview: Execute the command make install DESTDIR=${destroot} in ${workpath}.

Details: Understanding the destroot phase is critical to understanding MacPorts, because, unlike some port systems, MacPorts "stages" an installation into an intermediate location —not the final file destination. There are two main advantages to this method.

listitem.para: A port's files may be cleanly uninstalled because all files and locations are tracked.

Since a port's files are not installed into MacPorts directory structure until an activation phase, a port may be deactivated through MacPorts to allow activation of a different version of the same port, thus allowing two versions of a port to be present, though not both active, on a given host.

note.para: The $(DESTDIR) variable must be supported in an application's Makefile for the MacPorts destroot phase to work properly. Urge developers to fully support $(DESTDIR) in their Makefiles.

section.para: At the beginning of the destroot phase, all the directories in the file ${prefix}/etc/macports/prefix.mtree are created. Any directories still empty upon completion of the destroot phase are removed unless a directory is listed using a destroot.keepdirs keyword.

section.title: Archive
section.para: Overview: Use tar to create a tarball of a port's destrooted files and copy it to ${prefix}/var/macports/packages/.

section.title: Install
section.para: Overview: Copy a port's destrooted files into ${prefix}/var/macports/software. See Port Images in the MacPorts Internals chapter for details.

section.title: Activate
section.para: Overview: Set hardlinks pointing to ${prefix}/var/macports/software to point to ${prefix}.

section.title: Installation Phase Keywords
section.para: MacPorts keywords are used to specify required or optional items within a Portfile, or to override default options used by MacPorts base for individual ports. Keywords are to be used within the "global" and "variant" sections of Portfiles, and not within optional port phase declarations.

In other words, port phase keywords are not located within port phase declarations, but rather they refer to port phases and set options for those phases, and they take affect whether or not phase declarations have been explicitly defined in a Portfile.

section.title: A Word about Keyword List Modifiers (-append / -delete)
section.para: It is often necessary to add to a list of keyword values previously set by a previously executed Portfile keyword or by MacPorts base. To keep from overwriting a previous keyword list, use a keyword list modifier. Keywords that support list modifiers are identified under appropriate reference sections below.
The three most common uses for keyword list modifiers are to preserve configure defaults, to preserve PortGroup dependencies, and to add or delete items for variants.

section.title: Common Uses for Keyword List Modifiers
section.para: The three most common uses for keyword list modifiers are to preserve configure defaults, to preserve PortGroup dependencies, and to add or delete items for variants.

listitem.para: MacPorts base sets the gcc compiler flags CFLAGS and LDFLAGS for all ports using configure.cflags and configure.ldflags, therefore to keep from overwriting the default compiler flags use configure.cflags-append and configure.ldflags-append.

Ports in a PortGroup have default library dependencies set by MacPorts base. Therefore, never use depends_lib in ports belonging to a PortGroup or it will overwrite the default library dependencies. Instead, use depends_lib-append.

section.title: A Word about Keyword Argument Modifiers (.pre_args / .post_args)
section.para: Keywords that support pre_args and post_args are used to assemble command strings together in a row, as described in the reference sections below. But it should be noted that all keyword argument modifiers implicitly support keyword list modifiers. For example, the keyword configure.pre_args also supports configure.pre_args-append and configure.pre_args-delete.

section.title: Fetch Phase Keywords
section.para: The list of keywords related to the fetch phase.

listitem.para: A list of URLs from which a port's download file(s) may be retrieved. For multiple master_sites, they are searched in order until a file matching ${distfile} is found.
You may also use mirror site lists predefined by MacPorts. Here the sourceforge and gnu mirrors are used.

When using mirror master_sites, the subdirectory ${name} is checked on every mirror. If the mirror subdirectory does not match ${name}, then you may specify it using after the mirror separated by a colon.
For ports that must fetch multiple download files from different locations, you must label the files with tags and match the tags in a distfiles statement. The format is mirror:subdirectory:tag.
In the example below, file_one.tar.gz is fetched from sourceforge mirrors in subdirectory ${name}; file tagtwo.tar.gz is fetched from the gnu mirrors in subdirectory sources.
listitem.programlisting:
master_sites sourceforge::tagone \ gnu:sources:tagtwo
distfiles file_one.tar.gz:tagone \ file_two.tar.gz:tagtwo

listitem.para: Subdirectory to append to all mirror sites for any list specified in ${master_sites}.

section.para: Universal keywords are used to make a port compile on the OS X platform to run on either PPC or Intel.

note.para: There is a default universal variant made available to all ports by MacPorts base, so redefining universal keywords should only be done to make a given port compile if the default options fail to do so.

This keyword is for specifying whether or not it is safe for a port to use multiple cpus or multiple cores in parallel during its build phase. If a port is declared to be builadble this way, the option -j N may be passed to the make command if parallel builds are enabled system-wide. This can be obtained by setting buildmakejobs in macports.conf. The integer N refers to the number of parallel build threads.
